data.title: Feature Request: When opening Command Palette, have the last command used selected
data.body:
It's very common to have to run the same command multiple times in a row, it would be very nice if when opening the Command Palette, the last command used to be selected, so it's just a quick Enter and üí• !

Or better yet, when opening the Command Palette, have the most used commands at the top.

data.title: distinguish configurations base on pressing F5 (debug) or ctrl+F5 (launch)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I'd like to run one npm script defining a normal launch of an application by pressing ctrl+F5 (= launch the app) and the second npm script running the app in a debug mode by pressing F5 (= debug the app).

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Define 2 launch configurations.

```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
          "type": "node",
          "request": "launch",
          "name": "Launch Program",
          "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
          "runtimeExecutable": "npm",
          "runtimeArgs": [ "run-script", "start" ]
        },
        {
          "type": "node",
          "request": "launch",
          "name": "Debug Program",
          "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
          "runtimeExecutable": "npm",
          "runtimeArgs": [ "run-script", "debug" ]
        }
    ]
}

```
2. Run the first configuration by pressing ctrl+F5 and the second by pressing just F5 (debug mode).

data.title: Minimap: Add option to render blocks instead of characters
data.body:
From @sprinkle131313 

Extracted from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4865#issuecomment-281124983

---

What about this comment? https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4865#issuecomment-255368352

I'd prefer it over small unreadable text and it provides the information I need. I'm not sure how difficult it would be but by the sounds of it you could just create a new font where every character is just a solid square, minus whitespace.

---

Even when I really don't miss the minimap on @code, if I need to choose I can say I really like the minimap approach on Atom (plus, the code is OS). Is not a zoom-out version of the code, but a schematic representation. That is clever, because what you want is to quick identify sections of the code and not the code itself, and you can visually improve the key elements that make that possible, like color, line lenght, white space...

![2016-10-21_09h34_59](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6965667/19598661/5e904ffc-9772-11e6-8cad-995e38677d3c.png)

data.title: git errors more often now
data.body:
I know this is an evergreen but since we selfhost on the new git extension I see this a lot more frequent. It's usually enough to sync with ~5 incoming and ~2 outgoing changes

```
fatal: Unable to create '/Users/jrieken/Code/vscode/.git/index.lock': File exists.

Another git process seems to be running in this repository, e.g.
an editor opened by 'git commit'. Please make sure all processes
are terminated then try again. If it still fails, a git process
may have crashed in this repository earlier:
remove the file manually to continue.
could not detach HEAD
```

data.title: IntelliSense conflicts with Emmet in PHP files
data.body:
When writing Emmet code in a PHP file (for example .row>.medium-4.columns), pressing Tab will change the last part to the IntelliSense suggestion instead of executing the Emmet snippet.

The easiest way to fix this would be the ability to disable IntelliSense on Tab, but I could only find the option to disable using IntelliSense with the Enter button.

data.title: Hot Exit: Opens the same file twice in two separate windows
data.body:
For: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/16820

We have logic that decides on startup if files should open inside a separate window or new window. When we know that we open a window with a folder we always open files in that window. However we are not doing so when we know that we open a window with a folder that contains hot-exit files or an untitled window with hot-exit files.

This fix will prefer a folder with dirty files (or untitled window with dirty files to restore) to open the files in in order to fix https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/16820

data.title: Terminal encoding problem related to issue #14586
data.body: This PR try to fix the special chars encoding problem when the `$LANG` variable is not set on user's Mac. More information about this problem on #14586

data.title: VSCode doesn't remember a previous session

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-08T23:44:55.542Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-62-generic
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|MagicPython|magicstack|1.0.6|

---

My VSCode app never restores the previous session after exit (files I edited and the layout) and always opens up with a blank `Untitled-1` document. It seems not to be a canonical behavior, from the docs

> -n or --new-window - Opens a new session of VS Code instead of restoring the previous session (default).

data.title: Minimap: 2x1 font has too many irregularities

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Take the following code (`ITextModel` in `editorCommon`):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/23127718/531c6952-f77c-11e6-81d5-1ab7d4501b1a.png)

Today it looks like this in the minimap with the 2x1 font:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/23127775/8738d2c0-f77c-11e6-9110-8e8ac4026a65.png)

### 2x1 minimap zoomed in 400%:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/23127848/d56c4dfa-f77c-11e6-8a65-efb66090aa0d.png)

### Editor screenshot scaled down to 200px width and zoomed in 400%:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/23127982/6179d470-f77d-11e6-9d93-d74fc8cfdcad.png)

Notice, for example, the gray comments: in the scaled down version they have a lot less irregularities in terms of brightness.

The minimap font should have "a more consistent brightness".

data.title: Debug configurations with the same name
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->
If you have two debug configurations with the same name but different signature, and try to run any of them, it would run only the last one as this is the one the code resolves to. It is because it resolves configuration by name, not by a unique ID.

- VSCode Version: 1.10.0
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create two different debug configurations in launch.config with the same name.
2. Go to debug view, select first configuration and run. 
It will run second one defined in the launch.json, instead of the first one.

Expected: follow the same ordering as in launch.json.

ping @isidorn

data.title: Debugger clog icon does not exist
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-09T00:26:45.394Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|php-debug|felixfbecker|1.10.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:
I am attempting to setup PHP debugging but the cog icon is missing.

The following websites
https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/editor/debugging
and
https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/nicktrog/2016/02/11/configuring-visual-studio-code-for-php-development/

have a clog icon which creates a launch.json file for configuring the debugging extension. This icon does not exist on the debugging screen.

I have attached a screenshot demonstrating that the extension is installed and the cog icon is missing from the debugging screen. Please advise what I need to to rectify this.

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2111102/23124715/5047d024-f766-11e6-87fa-e30f47ca577e.PNG)
